channel.title: In_Progress on MathWiki
channel.description: Recent content in In_Progress on MathWiki

item.title: Subgroup
item.description: Definition and Characterizations A standard method of studying an object $-$ in this case, a group $G$ $-$ is to analyze other groups that ‘sit inside’ $G$. This is formalized in the following Definition. Let $G$ be a group. A subgroup of $G$ is a subset $H\subseteq G$ equipped with a group structure making the inclusion $H\into G$ a group homomorphism. Note that any subset $H\subseteq G$ inherits the operation from $G$, and makes it a subgroup iff said operation is closed.

item.title: Ideal
item.description: To study the quotient objects in a category, we must first understand the congruence relations in said category. For $\catring$, these are in correspondence with ideals. Definition. Let $R$ be a ring. A (left) ideal in $R$ is a subgroup $(\mf{a},+)\substructeq R$ such that $r\mf{a}\subseteq\mf{a}$ for all $r\in R$. Similarly for right ideals and two-sided ideals.

item.title: Module
item.description: Motivation & Definition Throughout, fix a ring $R$. Definition. A (left) $R$-module is an Abelian group $(M,+)$ equipped with a left $R$-action $R\to\End_\catabgrp(M)$. That is, a function $R\times M\to M$ such that $$\begin{equation} r(m+n)=rm+rn,\ \ \ \ (r+s)m=rm+sm,\ \ \ \ (rs)m=r(sm),\ \ \ \ \mathit{and}\ \ \ \ 1m=m \end{equation}$$ for all $r,s\in R$ and $m,n\in M$. The relevant structure-preserving maps for $R$-modules are as follows. Definition. A function $f:M\to N$ between $R$-modules is a homomorphism if it is a group homomorphism $f:(M,+)\to(N,+)$ such that

item.title: Ring
item.description: Motivation & Definition The concept of a ring naturally arises when studying the endomorphism group of an Abelian group $G$. Indeed, $\End G$ is itself Abelian $-$ but more importantly, it has an extra operation of composition. These operations are compatible in the sense of: Definition. A ring is a tuple $(R,+,\cdot,1)$ where $(R,\cdot,1)$ is a monoid, $(R,+)$ is an Abelian group, and where for all $r,s,t\in R$, we have $$\begin{equation} (r+s)\cdot t=r\cdot t+s\cdot t\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \mathit{and}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ t\cdot(r+s)=t\cdot r+t\cdot s.

item.title: Orbit Stabilizer Theorem
item.description: Statement & Proof Let $G\act X$ act on a set and fix $x_0\in X$. Theorem (Orbit-Stabilizer). Let $G$ be a group and let $(X,x_0)$ be a pointed $G$-set. Equipping $G/\Stab_G(x_0)$ with the natural left-multiplication $G$-action, we have a $G$-equivariant bijection $\Orb_G(x_0)\iso G/\Stab_G(x_0)$. Proof. Let $H\coloneqq\Stab_G(x_0)$ and consider the map $f:G\to\Orb_G(x_0):g\mapsto gx_0$. Since $$\begin{equation} f(g_1)=f(g_2)\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \Leftrightarrow\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ g_2^{-1}g_1x_0=x_0\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \Leftrightarrow\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ g_1H=g_2H, \end{equation}$$ we see that $f$ descends $^\dagger$ into an injective map $\widetilde{f}:G/H\to\Orb_G(x_0):gH\mapsto gx_0$.

item.title: Finite Group
item.description: Let $G$ be a group. The condition that (the underlying set of) $G$ is finite allows us to apply methods from finite combinatorics to analyze $G$. We give some group-theoretic frameworks for which such combinatorics can be applied to. Note that such methods can become incredibly sophisticated; the classification of finite simple groups is one of the major achievements of mathematics. Group Actions on Sets The Orbit-Stabilizer Theorem Let $G\act X$ $-$ where $X$ is a possibly infinite set $-$ and fix an orbit $O\coloneqq\Orb_G(x_0)$ for any $x_0\in X$.

item.title: Completeness of Category of Groups
item.description: Existence of (Co)limits Proposition. Concrete Descriptions of (Co)limits Products/Coproducts Kernels/Cokernels

item.title: Free Group
item.description: Motivation & Definition Fix a set $X$. We would like to construct a group $F(X)$ containing $X$ ‘canonically’ and ‘in the most efficient way’. The latter is encoded by a universal property, and the former makes $F:\catset\to\catgrp$ a left-adjoint to the forgetful functor $U:\catgrp\to\catset$. Definition. Let $X$ be a set. A free group on $X$ is a group $F(X)$ equipped with a function $j:X\to F(X)$ that is universal in the following sense:

item.title: Integers
item.description: The set of integers $-$ denoted $\Z$ $-$ is one of the most fundamental objects in all of mathematics. In group theory, it is the free-group on one generator; in ring theory, it is the initial object in $\catring$; in graph theory, it is the unique degree $2$ tree; etc. Construction Initial Object in $\catring$ As all nice objects do, it is characterized by a certain universal property. $\Z$-modules Graph Theory

item.title: Order
item.description: Definition. Let $G$ be a group. An element $x\in G$ is has finite order if we have $x^n=e$ for some $n>0$; the least such $n$ is the order of $x$, denoted $\ord x$. Otherwise, set $\ord x\coloneqq\infty$, and say that $x$ has infinite order. Remark. More abstractly, for a fixed $x\in G$, consider the map $\phi_x:\Z\to G$ induced uniquely by sending $1\mapsto x$, and set $\ord x\coloneqq\l|\im\phi_x\r|$. If $\ker\phi_x=n\Z$ for some $n>0$, then $\im\phi_x\iso\Z/n\Z$ has cardinality $n$.

item.title: Cyclic Group
item.description: Motivation & Definition The simplest class of groups are the so-called cyclic groups, which are those that are generated by a single element. Definition. A group $G$ is said to be cyclic if $G=\gen{x}$ $^\dagger$ for some $x\in G$. Classification Let $G=\gen{x}$ be cyclic. By definition, $\phi:\Z\to G$ sending $m\mapsto x^m$ is surjective. Depending on the order $n\coloneqq\ord x$ of $x$, $G$ takes on the following forms. If $1\leq n<\infty$, then $\ker\phi=n\Z$ and hence $G\iso\Z/n\Z$.

item.title: Limits & Colimits
item.description: Motivation & Definition Fix a category $C$. Definition. Let $C,J$ be categories and fix a functor $F\in C^J$. A colimit of $F$ is a universal arrow $(r,u)$ from $F$ to the diagonal functor $\Delta:C\to C^J$. Similarly, a limit of $F$ is a universal arrow $(t,v)$ from $\Delta$ to $F$. Representable Functors Universal Elements Examples (Co)products (Co)equalizers Fibered (Co)products Directed (Co)limits

item.title: The Yoneda Lemma
item.description: The Yoneda Embedding $\yo$ Statement & Proof Fix a locally-small category $C$. $\yo:C\to\catset$ Theorem (Yoneda). Let $C$ be a locally-small category. For every functor $F:C\to\catset$ and every object $c\in C$, we have a bijection $$\begin{equation} y\coloneqq y_{F,c}:\Hom(C(c,\slot),F)\to Fc\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \mathit{sending}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \big(\eta:C(c,\slot)\to F\big)\mapsto\eta_c1_c, \end{equation}$$ which is moreover natural in both $F$ and $c$. Proof (Bijection). Define a function $t\coloneqq t_{F,c}:Fc\to\Hom(C(C,\slot),F)$ by sending an element $a\in Fc$ to the natural transformation $t(a):C(c,\slot)\to F$ via $$\begin{equation} t(a)_d:C(c,d)\to Fd\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \textrm{mapping}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ (f:c\rightarrow d)\mapsto Ff(a)\in Fd \end{equation}$$ for each $d\in C$.

item.title: Universal Constructions
item.description: Motivation & Definition Universal Arrows Definition. Let $F:D\to C$ be a functor and fix $c\in C$. A universal arrow from $c$ to $F$ is an initial object in $(c\downto F)$. That is, it is a pair $(r,u)$, with $r\in D$ and $u:c\to Fr$, inducing for each $d\in D$ a bijection $$\begin{equation} \phi_d:D(r,d)\to C(c,Fd):f’\mapsto Ff’\circ u. \end{equation}$$ This can be visualized as in the following diagram. Remark. The bijection $\phi_d$ is natural in $d$, for if $g’:d\to d’$, then $$\begin{equation} F(g’\circ f’)\circ u=Fg’\circ(Ff’\circ u) \end{equation}$$ for every morphism $f’:r\to d$, making its naturality square commute.

item.title: Natural Transformation
item.description: Motivation & Definition Definition. Let $F,G:C\to D$ be covariant functors between categories $C$ and $D$. A natural transformation $\eta:F\to G$ is a function assigning to each $c\in C$ a morphism $\eta_c:Fc\to Gc$ of $D$ such that for every $f\in C(c,c’)$, the diagram commutes.

item.title: Category
item.description: Motivation & Definition The starting point of the theory of categories is the observation that many properties of mathematical objects can be more succinctly expressed as diagrams of arrows $-$ as opposed to an equation $-$ and that many objects can be constructed via a ‘universal property’ of such a diagram; heuristically then, these objects are characterized as the ‘most efficient solution to a certain optimization problem’. To formalize this, we need a general framework for composing arrows, so we make the following
